In this section, we describe the computation of class average feature norm. To facilitate our discussion, we enumerate key notations in Table 1.
In a federated learning scenario for image classification tasks involving n𝑛n participants, each participant Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i} possesses a local dataset denoted as Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i} with nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} labeled samples:

Metrics for performance evaluation are presented in Table 3, where the T​r​a​f​f​i​c𝑇𝑟𝑎𝑓𝑓𝑖𝑐Traffic represents the cumulative data exchanged, including both uploads and downloads, and T​i​m​e𝑇𝑖𝑚𝑒Time computes the duration to complete 10 rounds of training.
The metrics κ=A​c​c​u​r​a​c​y∗104/T​i​m​e𝜅𝐴𝑐𝑐𝑢𝑟𝑎𝑐𝑦superscript104𝑇𝑖𝑚𝑒\kappa=Accuracy*{10^{4}}/Time and ρ=A​c​c​u​r​a​c​y∗104/T​r​a​f​f​i​c𝜌𝐴𝑐𝑐𝑢𝑟𝑎𝑐𝑦superscript104𝑇𝑟𝑎𝑓𝑓𝑖𝑐\rho=Accuracy*{10^{4}}/Traffic were computed to measure test accuracy per unit of time and traffic, respectively, providing a quantifiable representation of efficiency and data economy of each algorithm.
Among tested FL algorithms, FNR-FL stands out for its exceptional efficiency in non-i.i.d scenarios, such as a κ𝜅\kappa of 1.6462 and a ρ𝜌\rho of 1.1184 in feature distribution skew. This overarching superiority of FNR-FL stems from its robust algorithmic structure that ensures high accuracy without disproportionately increasing communication or computational cost.

references: In more realistic and challenging settings, where data distributions are often mixed, we evaluated the performance of federated learning algorithms on the CIFAR-10 dataset under combined scenarios of label and feature distribution skew as well as label and quantity distribution skew. Our findings are summarized in Table 4.

S6.T5.caption: Table 5: Orthogonality of FNR-FL with existing FL algorithms (ResNet-18, CIFAR-10)
S6.T5.table:
Non-i.i.d scenarios Feature distribution skew Label distribution skew Quantity skew
FedAvg+FNR-FL 0.9976 0.9970 0.9982
FedProx+FNR-FL 0.9784 0.9838 0.9999
SCAFFOLD+FNR-FL 0.9783 0.9892 0.9637
MOON+FNR-FL 0.9678 0.9774 0.9532
FedNova+FNR-FL 0.9664 0.9766 0.9427
references:
The experimental results in Table 5 demonstrate the effectiveness of integrating the FNR-FL algorithm with other FL algorithms.
Across all scenarios, combinations involving FNR-FL consistently outperform their standalone FL algorithms, indicating a substantial enhancement in handling non-i.i.d data distributions. Specifically, FedAvg+FNR-FL emerges as a top performer in feature and label distribution skews, achieving accuracies of 0.9976 and 0.9970 respectively, while FedProx+FNR-FL leads in the quantity skew scenario with an accuracy of 0.9999. These results suggest that FNR-FL’s regularization mechanism effectively complements and augments existing FL algorithms [34].

S6.T6.table:
Non-i.i.d setting Noise FNR-FL FedAvg FedProx SCAFFOLD MOON FedNova
Feature distribution skew 0.0 0.9995 0.9238 0.9039 0.9290 0.7371 0.9257
0.1 0.9984 0.8549 0.8219 0.8581 0.5677 0.8469

Label distribution skew 0.0 0.9970 0.8850 0.8773 0.9077 0.6515 0.9043
0.1 0.9755 0.8067 0.7837 0.8371 0.6360 0.8029
0.5 0.9111 0.4504 0.4587 0.5763 0.3728 0.3942
references:
The experiment evaluates the performance and robustness of FNR-FL against other FL algorithms across different noise levels within feature and label distribution skews. The results are presented in Table 6.
In the feature distribution skew, FNR-FL consistently maintains the highest accuracy, indicating a strong resilience to noise. With a standard deviation (SD) of 0.0 (no noise), FNR-FL achieves near-perfect accuracy (0.9995), significantly outperforming the next best algorithm, SCAFFOLD, by a margin of 7%. As noise increases (SDs of 0.1 and 0.5), FNR-FL notably sustains a lesser degree of decline relative to other algorithms.
A similar pattern is observed in label distribution skew scenarios.
These findings suggest that FNR-FL is robust against noise in the data. This resilience to noise highlights the algorithm’s potential for practical deployment in federated learning scenarios [38].
